1 HW 1

The first two problems of this homework are intended to primarily be a review of the programming techniques that you will need for this class. The problems mention the Law of Large Numbers, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing. You do not need to know anything about the statistical theory behind them in order to solve these problems.

The Law of Large Numbers tells us that as n ‚Üí ‚àû n\rightarrow \infty n‚Üí‚àû the sample average defined by

X ‚Äæ ‚â° 1 n ‚àë i = 1 n X i \displaystyle \overline{X}\equiv\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_i X‚â°n1‚Äãi=1‚àën‚ÄãXi‚Äã

will be near the population average Œº \mu Œº with a given probability. Given n n n samples from a population, we don‚Äôt expect X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X to exactly match Œº \mu Œº. The Law of Large Numbers allows us to make a statement about the difference X ‚Äæ ‚àí Œº \overline{X}-\mu X‚àíŒº. Specifically, the statement involves the probability that ‚à£ X ‚Äæ ‚àí Œº ‚à£ |\overline{X}-\mu| ‚à£X‚àíŒº‚à£ is smaller that a certain value.

If you are interested, for a more formal definition of the Law of Large Numbers and proofs, see

  • Orloff and Bloom, Reading 6b
  • Bulmer, Chapter 6 (Piazza)
  • DeGroot, Chapter 6 (Piazza)

  1. Draw n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100 values from a population of numbers drawn from a gaussian distribution with mean Œº = 0 \mu=0 Œº=0 and standard deviation œÉ = 1 \sigma=1 œÉ=1.
  2. Compute X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X.
  3. Repeat 1. and 2. 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 times and plot a histogram of X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X.

Save your program as HW1_1a.py. When I execute your program, I should see a histogram with the average of X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X displayed in the title.

Answer

See HW1_1a.py. Several students turned in plots without axis labels ü§∑. I should not have to ask and I should really give a zero to make the point that it is never acceptable to create a plot with missing or incorrect labels.

1.1.2 b

  1. For n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100, what fraction of the 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 X ‚Äæ \overline{X} Xs were in the range [ ‚àí 0 . 0 1 , 0 . 0 1 ] [-0.01, 0.01] [‚àí0.01,0.01]?
  2. How does the fraction depend on n n n? +
  3. For n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100, what is the range [ ‚àí œµ , œµ ] [-\epsilon,\epsilon] [‚àíœµ,œµ] for which 9 9 99 99% of the 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 X ‚Äæ \overline{X} Xs fall in?
  4. How does œµ \epsilon œµ depend on n n n? +
  5. How does your answer change if the distribution changes?

+ You may explain this using one or more of words, tables, and plots.

Save your program as HW1_1b.py. Save your answers in a file named HW1_1b.md or HW1_1b.pdf.

Answer

See HW1_1b.py

  1. 7.6%

  2. The following plot shows the dependence. As n n n increases, the standard deviation of the histogram of X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X decreases so that more of the distribution is in the range [ ‚àí 0 . 0 1 , 0 . 0 1 ] [-0.01, 0.01] [‚àí0.01,0.01].

  3. 25.8%

  4. The following plot shows the dependence.

  5. I accepted any answer to this question as it was not interpreted correctly. By ‚Äúdistribution‚Äù, I mean the type of distribution, e.g., Gaussian, uniform, lognormal, etc. If you choose parameters for these distributions such that their mean is zero, the results are unchanged. This is a consequence of the Central Limit Theorem. It does not matter how the n n n X X Xs are distributed, the distribution of X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X is still Gaussian. In HW1_1a.py, there is a line with np.random.uniform commented out. Try running the code with it uncommented and notice that the histogram is still Gaussian even though a uniform distribution was used for the n n n X ‚Äæ \overline{X} Xs.

1.2 Prelude to Hypothesis Testing

This problem is a prelude to the frequentist interpretation of probability and hypothesis testing.

I select n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100 men at random from the U.S. population and compute the average of their heights. Using only the techniques used in the previous problem, make a statement about the likelihood that the actual U.S. population average is more than 1 inch larger or smaller than the average of the n n n heights.

Briefly describe a program that you would write to determine the likelihood. If you have done hypothesis testing before, don‚Äôt use any of its terminology or techniques. I am only interested in hearing ideas that you have about how the approach used in the previous problem could be used to give an answer.

Save your answer in a file named HW1_2.md or HW1_2.pdf.

Answer

In this problem, a single sample of n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100 was used to compute an average, X ‚Äæ o \overline{X}_o Xo‚Äã and standard deviation s o s_o so‚Äã. We do not know the population average Œº \mu Œº but want to make a statement (or ‚Äúinference‚Äù) about it.

Now do many (say 10,000) experiments of drawing a sample of 1 0 0 100 100 values from a gaussian distribution with mean X ‚Äæ o \overline{X}_o Xo‚Äã and sample standard deviation s o s_o so‚Äã. That is, assume that the actual unknown population distribution has a mean and standard deviation that is equal to that from the sample.

The percentage of 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 experiments that had an X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X that was one inch larger or smaller than X ‚Äæ o \overline{X}_o Xo‚Äã is our estimate of the likelihood.

The above is the basic process of inferential statistics. However, instead of doing a simulation of 10,000 experiments, one can use a table to look up the expected percentage when an infinite number of experiments are performed.

1.3 Basic Concepts in Probability

Read Chapter 2.1-2.2 of Devore, 2012 (PDF available on Piazza).

  1. An experiment involves tossing a coin 3x. What is the sample space of this experiment?
  2. How many of the outcomes in the sample space had two heads?
  3. Define event A A A to be that the experiment yields two heads. Define event B B B to be that the experiment yields two tails. What is A ‚à™ B A \cup B A‚à™B and A ‚à© B A \cap B A‚à©B?

Save your answers in a file named HW1_3a.md or HW1_3a.pdf.

Answer

  1. The sample space has 8 elements ( 2 3 2^3 23). This list can be found using a tree diagram as shown below.

            H   => HHH
    H -
        T   => HHT
H -        
        H   => HTH
    T -
        T   => HTT

        H   => THH
    H -
        T   => THT
T -        
        H   => TTH
    T -
        T   => TTT

  2. 3 3 3 by inspection of the table above. Also, suppose that we have three unique coins T T T, H 1 H_1 H1‚Äã, and H 2 H_2 H2‚Äã. There are 3 ! 3! 3! unique permutations. If we drop the subscripts, then the number of unique permutations is divided by 2. So 3 ! / 2 = 3 3!/2=3 3!/2=3.

  3. By inspection of the list from 1., A ‚à™ B = 6 A \cup B = 6 A‚à™B=6 and A ‚à© B = ‚àÖ A \cap B = \emptyset A‚à©B=‚àÖ.

In the above, I assumed ‚Äúexperiement yields two heads‚Äù to mean ‚Äúthe experiment yielded exactly two heads‚Äù and not ‚Äúthe experiement yielded two or more heads‚Äù.

2.1 Counting

  1. By hand, solve problem 38. in Chapter 2. of Devore. See Piazza for a copy of this chapter. (Save as HW2_1_1.pdf or HW2_1_1.md)
  2. Use Python to check your answer by simulating many experiments in which 3 bulbs are randomly selected and then computing the ratios requested in parts a.‚Äìd. of the problem statement. This will not be an exact answer, but as you increase the number of experiments, this approximate answer should become closer to your answers found by hand. (Save as HW2_1_2.py)

Update: Technically parts a.-c. ask for drawing three bulbs, so the inclusion of part d in the above does not make sense. So just use the simulation to check your answers to parts a.-c., but you are encouraged to use a simulation to check your answer to part d.

Answer

A box in a certain supply room contains four 40-W light-bulbs, five 60-W bulbs, and six 75-W bulbs. Suppose that three bulbs are randomly selected.

a. What is the probability that exactly two of the selected bulbs are rated at 75-W?

Consider the number of ways of getting [ 7 5 , 7 5 , 4 0 ] [75,75,40] [75,75,40]. It is 6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 4 6\cdot 5\cdot 4 6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4. There are three ways to order this list, so the total number of ways of getting two 75s and one 40 is 3 ( 6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 4 ) 3(6\cdot 5\cdot 4) 3(6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4). From similar reasoning, it follows that the number of ways of getting [ 7 5 , 7 5 , 4 0 ] [75,75,40] [75,75,40] in any order is 3 ( 6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 5 ) 3(6\cdot 5\cdot 5) 3(6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ5). The total probability is thus

3 ( 6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 4 + 6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 5 ) 1 5 ‚ãÖ 1 4 ‚ãÖ 1 3 ‚âà 0 . 2 9 7 \displaystyle \displaystyle \frac{3(6\cdot 5\cdot 4 + 6\cdot 5\cdot 5)}{15\cdot 14\cdot 13}\approx 0.297 15‚ãÖ14‚ãÖ133(6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4+6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ5)‚Äã‚âà0.297

b. What is the probability that all three of the selected bulbs have the same rating?

The number of ways of getting ‚Äúthree of a kind‚Äù is the number of ways of getting three 75s plus the number of ways of getting three 60s plus the number of ways of getting three 40s, which is

6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 4 + 5 ‚ãÖ 4 ‚ãÖ 3 + 4 ‚ãÖ 3 ‚ãÖ 2 \displaystyle 6\cdot 5\cdot 4 + 5\cdot 4\cdot 3 + 4\cdot 3 \cdot 2 6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4+5‚ãÖ4‚ãÖ3+4‚ãÖ3‚ãÖ2

The requested probability is thus

6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 4 + 5 ‚ãÖ 4 ‚ãÖ 3 + 4 ‚ãÖ 3 ‚ãÖ 2 1 5 ‚ãÖ 1 4 ‚ãÖ 1 3 ‚âà 0 . 0 7 5 \displaystyle \frac{6\cdot 5\cdot 4 + 5\cdot 4\cdot 3 + 4\cdot 3 \cdot 2}{15\cdot 14\cdot 13}\approx 0.075 15‚ãÖ14‚ãÖ136‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4+5‚ãÖ4‚ãÖ3+4‚ãÖ3‚ãÖ2‚Äã‚âà0.075

c. What is the probability that one bulb of each type is selected?

The number of ways of getting [ 7 5 , 6 0 , 4 0 ] [75,60,40] [75,60,40] is 6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 4 6\cdot 5\cdot 4 6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4. There are 3 ‚ãÖ 2 = 6 {3\cdot 2}=6 3‚ãÖ2=6 arrangements of this list.

The requested probability is thus

6 ( 6 ‚ãÖ 5 ‚ãÖ 4 ) 1 5 ‚ãÖ 1 4 ‚ãÖ 1 3 ‚âà 0 . 2 6 \displaystyle \frac{6(6\cdot 5\cdot 4)}{15\cdot 14\cdot 13}\approx 0.26 15‚ãÖ14‚ãÖ136(6‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ4)‚Äã‚âà0.26

d. Suppose now that bulbs are to be selected one by one until a 75-W bulb is found. What is the probability that it is necessary to examine at least 6 bulbs?

  1. See HW2_1_2.py

2.2 Bayes‚Äô Theorem

2% of people age 50‚Äì60 who participate in routine screening have colon cancer. 80% of people with colon cancer will test positive. 9.6% of those without colon cancer will also test positive. A person in this age group had a positive test in a routine screening. What is the probability that they actually have colon cancer?

Draw diagrams and be prepared to explain your answer to the class. If you do not know how to solve this analytically, come up with a simulation to give an approximate answer.

(Save as HW2_2.pdf or HW2_2.md)

Answer

  • P ( N ) = 0 . 9 8 P(N) = 0.98 P(N)=0.98 (probability of No cancer)
  • P ( C ) = 0 . 0 2 P(C) = 0.02 P(C)=0.02 (probability of Cancer)
  • P ( T + ‚à£ C ‚Äæ ) = 0 . 0 9 6 P(T^+|\overline{C}) = 0.096 P(T+‚à£C)=0.096 (probability of false positive)
  • P ( T + ‚à£ C ) = 0 . 8 0 P(T^+|C) = 0.80 P(T+‚à£C)=0.80 (probability of +Test given Cancer)
  • P ( C ‚à£ T + ) = ? P(C|T^+) = ? P(C‚à£T+)=? (probability of cancer given +Test)

We can‚Äôt apply Bayes‚Äô rule
P ( C ) = P ( T + ) P ( C ‚à£ T + ) P ( T + ‚à£ C ) \displaystyle P(C) = P(T^+)\frac{P(C|T^+)}{P(T^+|C)} P(C)=P(T+)P(T+‚à£C)P(C‚à£T+)‚Äã

rewritten as

P ( C ‚à£ T + ) = P ( C ) ‚ãÖ P ( T + ‚à£ C ) P ( T + ) \displaystyle P(C|T^+)=\frac{P(C)\cdot P(T^+|C)}{P(T^+)} P(C‚à£T+)=P(T+)P(C)‚ãÖP(T+‚à£C)‚Äã

immediately, because we need P ( T + ) P(T^+) P(T+). To get this, first compute the number of patients that get a positive colon cancer test
n T + = n C P ( T + ‚à£ C ) + n N P ( T + ‚à£ N ) \displaystyle n_{T^+}=n_{C}P(T^+|C)+n_{N}P(T^+|N) nT+‚Äã=nC‚ÄãP(T+‚à£C)+nN‚ÄãP(T+‚à£N)

where n X n_{X} nX‚Äã is the number of patients in category X X X. Divide through by the total number of patients to get
P ( T + ) = P ( C ) P ( T + ‚à£ C ) + P ( N ) P ( T + ‚à£ N ) \displaystyle P(T^+)=P(C)P(T^+|C)+P(N)P(T^+|N) P(T+)=P(C)P(T+‚à£C)+P(N)P(T+‚à£N)

then

P ( C ‚à£ T + ) = P ( C ) ‚ãÖ P ( T + ‚à£ C ) P ( C ) P ( T + ‚à£ C ) + P ( N ) P ( T + ‚à£ N ) \displaystyle P(C|T^+)\frac{}{}=\frac{P(C)\cdot P(T^+|C)}{P(C)P(T^+|C)+P(N)P(T^+|N)} P(C‚à£T+)‚Äã=P(C)P(T+‚à£C)+P(N)P(T+‚à£N)P(C)‚ãÖP(T+‚à£C)‚Äã

inserting numbers gives

P ( C ‚à£ T + ) = 0 . 0 2 ‚ãÖ 0 . 8 0 . 0 2 ‚ãÖ 0 . 8 + 0 . 9 8 ‚ãÖ 0 . 0 9 6 = 0 . 1 4 5 \displaystyle P(C|T^+) = \frac{0.02\cdot 0.8}{0.02\cdot 0.8+0.98 \cdot 0.096} = 0.145 P(C‚à£T+)=0.02‚ãÖ0.8+0.98‚ãÖ0.0960.02‚ãÖ0.8‚Äã=0.145

So the probability of actually having colon cancer given a postive test is about 1 4 . 5 % 14.5\% 14.5%.

(Often students report their answer to many more than 2 significant digits. How would you calculate the appropriate number of significant digits and the uncertainty in your reported answer, based on the numbers given?)

Alternative Approach I

The information given can be summarized in the following table. The first row contains the true positives (TPs) and false positives (FPs). For a population of 1000, there will be 20 people that have cancer, and 980 that do not. Of the 20 that have cancer, 16 will test positive. Of the 980 that do not have cancer, 9 8 0 ‚ãÖ 0 . 9 6 = 9 4 980\cdot 0.96=94 980‚ãÖ0.96=94 will test positive.

      Have Cancer (20)    Don't Have Cancer (980)
T^+   16 (TP)             94 (FP)
T^-   4 (FN)

The marginal probability of having cancer given a positive test is the fraction of the true positives to the false positives.

P ( C ‚à£ T + ) = 1 6 1 6 + 9 4 = 0 . 1 4 5 \displaystyle P(C|T^+) = \frac{16}{16+94} = 0.145 P(C‚à£T+)=16+9416‚Äã=0.145

Alternative Approach II

To explain this calculation to someone, I would say:

Out of 1 0 0 0 1000 1000 people, 2 0 20 20 will have cancer ( 2 % ) (2\%) (2%). Sixteen of the 2 0 20 20 ( 8 0 % ) (80\%) (80%) will have a positive test, the other four will have a negative test.

This leaves 980 without cancer. However, 9 8 0 ‚ãÖ 0 . 0 9 6 = 9 4 980\cdot 0.096 = 94 980‚ãÖ0.096=94 of these cancer‚Äìfree people will still have a positive test. This is a large number of false positives!

If you received a positive test, you are one of the checked boxes. The number of checked boxes is 9 4 + 1 6 = 1 1 0 94+16=110 94+16=110 and 1 6 16 16 of them have cancer. So given a positive test, your chances are 1 6 / 1 1 0 16/110 16/110, or about a 1 1 1 in 1 4 14 14 chance.

See also How to Improve Bayesian Reasoning Without Instruction: Frequency Formats for a discussion on how to explain problems involving Bayesian reasoning.

3 HW 3

3.1 Exact answer for coin flips

In HW 1.3, you considered the question of the probability of getting two heads when flipping a fair coin 3x. This question was easily answered by explicitly writing out the sample space (the set of all possible outcomes) using a tree diagram and counting the number of outcomes with two heads.

Write out the sample space for four flips of a fair coin using a tree diagram and then by inspection of the diagram determine the probability of getting exactly two heads.

Next, inspect the sample space and provide an argument for why, if the probability of heads is Œ∏ \theta Œ∏, then the probability of k k k heads in N N N tosses is

P ( k ) = ( N k ) ( 1 ‚àí Œ∏ ) N ‚àí k Œ∏ k \displaystyle P(k)={N \choose k}(1-\theta)^{N-k}\theta^k P(k)=(kN‚Äã)(1‚àíŒ∏)N‚àíkŒ∏k

Do this using counting techniques with an explanation at the level that I used to explain the number of possible license plates of length three using only numbers. I used this example to give answers to the number of 3-digit license plates that could be formed using stickers with a digit (0-9) on them under three different constraints:

  1. An infinite supply of stickers: 1 0 3 10^3 103;
  2. A supply of 10 stickers, one for each digit: 1 0 ‚ãÖ 9 ‚ãÖ 8 = 1 0 ! / 7 ! 10\cdot 9\cdot 8 = 10!/7! 10‚ãÖ9‚ãÖ8=10!/7!;
  3. Same as 2., but also a license plate with the same three numbers as another license plate (but in a different order) being counted as the same license plate: 1 0 ! / ( 7 ! 3 ! ) = ( 1 0 3 ) 10!/(7!3!) = {10 \choose 3} 10!/(7!3!)=(310‚Äã).

You do not need to use a license plate/sticker analogy ‚Äì use whatever you need to explain the equation at a fundamental level. Save your answer as HW3_1.pdf or HW3_1.md and be prepared to explain your answer to the class.

Answer

There are a number of ways of answering this that I went over in class that are outlined below.

  1. Start with Œ∏ = 0 . 5 \theta=0.5 Œ∏=0.5 and explain the ( N k ) {N \choose k} (kN‚Äã) and then state that the probability is ( N k ) {N \choose k} (kN‚Äã) divided by the number of possible sequences, which is 2 N 2^N 2N.
  2. The case with Œ∏ ‚â† 0 . 5 \theta\ne 0.5 Œ∏‚â†0.5 can be explained by a tree diagram with weights of Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ and 1 ‚àí Œ∏ 1-\theta 1‚àíŒ∏ associated with each branch. The total probability of a path along a branch is the product of the branch weights (due to the product rule).

Based on the responses in class, I think most students understand the justification for this equation. I encourage you to always have an explanation like those described in class for any equation that you encounter. This invaribly makes explaining complex problems easier because you have a starting problem to build on.

3.2 Bayes‚Äô Rule Derivation and Terminology

You only need the law of multiplication to derive Bayes‚Äô theorem. The law of multiplication is

P ( A  and  B ) = P ( A ) P ( B ‚à£ A ) \displaystyle P(A\text{ and }B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(A and B)=P(A)P(B‚à£A)

The labels A A A and B B B are arbitrary. Swapping them gives:

P ( B  and  A ) = P ( B ) P ( A ‚à£ B ) \displaystyle P(B\text{ and }A)=P(B)P(A|B) P(B and A)=P(B)P(A‚à£B)

P ( B  and  A ) P(B\text{ and }A) P(B and A) means the same thing as P ( A  and  B ) P(A\text{ and }B) P(A and B) (mathematically, the set intersection A  and  B A\text{ and }B A and B is commutative). Equating the above two equations gives

P ( B ) P ( A ‚à£ B ) = P ( A ) P ( B ‚à£ A ) \displaystyle P(B)P(A|B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(B)P(A‚à£B)=P(A)P(B‚à£A)

Bayes‚Äô theorem (‚Äútheorem‚Äù, ‚Äúrule‚Äù, and ‚Äúlaw‚Äù are all used, seemingly arbitrarily) is

P ( A ‚à£ B ) = P ( B ‚à£ A ) P ( A ) P ( B ) \displaystyle P(A|B)=P(B|A)\frac{P(A)}{P(B)} P(A‚à£B)=P(B‚à£A)P(B)P(A)‚Äã

In this form,

  • P ( A ‚à£ B ) P(A|B) P(A‚à£B) is called the posterior. It is a probability that we compute after (post) consideration of the other probabilities.
  • P ( B ‚à£ A ) P(B|A) P(B‚à£A) is called the likelihood (this is a poor choice of name)
  • P ( A ) P(A) P(A) is called the prior. If B B B and A A A are independent, then P ( A ‚à£ B ) = P ( A ) P(A|B)=P(A) P(A‚à£B)=P(A), so P ( A ) P(A) P(A) is the probability prior to knowing any relationship between A A A and B B B.
  • P ( B ) P(B) P(B) is called a normalizing factor [Wall and Jenkins, p26] or, when B B B is evidence and A A A is a hypothesis, P ( B ) P(B) P(B) is also referred to as the evidence.

Another form of Bayes‚Äô theorem, valid when the events A j A_j Aj‚Äã are mutually exclusive and exhaustive, has the denominator re-written using the law of total probability, which is

P ( B ) = ‚àë j = 1 k P ( A j ) P ( B ‚à£ A j ) . \displaystyle P(B) = \sum_{j=1}^kP(A_j)P(B|A_j). P(B)=j=1‚àëk‚ÄãP(Aj‚Äã)P(B‚à£Aj‚Äã).

In this case, Bayes‚Äô theorem is

P ( A j ‚à£ B ) = P ( B ‚à£ A j ) P ( A j ) ‚àë j = 1 k P ( A j ) P ( B ‚à£ A j ) . \displaystyle P(A_j|B)=P(B|A_j)\frac{P(A_j)}{\sum_{j=1}^kP(A_j)P(B|A_j)}. P(Aj‚Äã‚à£B)=P(B‚à£Aj‚Äã)‚àëj=1k‚ÄãP(Aj‚Äã)P(B‚à£Aj‚Äã)P(Aj‚Äã)‚Äã.

In class, a student noted that the equation P ( A  and  B ) = P ( A ) P ( B ‚à£ A ) P(A\text{ and }B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(A and B)=P(A)P(B‚à£A) was not intuitively obvious and I gave an example to justify the equation that involved throwing darts at two overlapping circles labeled A A A and B B B; then I drew 10 dots corresponding to dart tosses and computed each term in the equation P ( A  and  B ) = P ( A ) P ( B ‚à£ A ) P(A\text{ and }B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(A and B)=P(A)P(B‚à£A) by inspection.

Come up with your own basic explanation/justification for the Law of Total Probability in a spirit similar to my dart-tossing example. Save your answer as HW3_2.pdf or HW3_2.md and be prepared to explain your answer to the class.

Answer

The responses to this question were not quite what I was looking for ‚Äì many students did not address the ‚Äúexhaustive and exclusive‚Äù requirement.

My answer involved a square dartboard with partitions labeled A j A_j Aj‚Äã. Region B B B was a shape that enclosed parts of at least two A j A_j Aj‚Äã regions. Based on this diagram, it is fairly straightforward to see how the Law of Total Probability is related to geometric areas. This is something that is considered also in the book by Stone referenced in the next problem.

3.3 Bayes‚Äô Rule for Statistical Inference

References

All of the following references describe the problem covered in this HW problem (see Piazza for PDFs). I‚Äôve attempted to write this problem in a way that you won‚Äôt need to study these references and I recommend attempting to solve this problem before reading them.

  • Silva 2006, Chapter 2.1. In this problem, I am walking you through the steps needed to create Figures 1. and 2. This book uses a somewhat unconventional notation by explicitly including the variable I I I. You can safely ignore it in the equations written.
  • The coin-tossing experiment is covered at a basic level in Chapters 1 and 4 of Stone.
  • A much more mathematically advanced description of this problem is given in Liu and Wasserman 2014.

I don‚Äôt expect you to be able to solve these problems without questions! Please be active on Piazza and Discord.

Let Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ be a parameter, such as a length, or, as considered in this problem, a probability. For example, suppose a computer program is created that prints an H H H with probability Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ and a T T T with probability 1 ‚àí Œ∏ 1-\theta 1‚àíŒ∏ or a coin is manufactured so that the probability of heads is exactly Œ∏ \theta Œ∏.

Let D \mathcal{D} D be data from an experiment, for example the results of coin flips, e.g., D = [ H , T , H , T ] \mathcal{D}=[H,T,H,T] D=[H,T,H,T]. With these variables, Bayes‚Äô theorem is

P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) = P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) P ( Œ∏ ) P ( D ) \displaystyle P(\theta|\mathcal{D})=P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)\frac{P(\theta)}{P(\mathcal{D})} P(Œ∏‚à£D)=P(D‚à£Œ∏)P(D)P(Œ∏)‚Äã

Suppose that we don‚Äôt know what Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ is ‚Äì we are given a coin from a machine and we don‚Äôt know if the machine produces a fair coin or not.

A typical Bayesian inference problem seeks to assign a probability of Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ given a set of measurements (data). That is, to assign a value to P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) P(\theta|\mathcal{D}) P(Œ∏‚à£D). In class, I discussed the case where we only had one or two measurements from coin tosses, that is, D = [ H ] \mathcal{D}=[H] D=[H], and D = [ H , T ] \mathcal{D}=[H, T] D=[H,T], respectively. In this problem, you will consider these two cases in detail.

For D = [ H ] \mathcal{D}=[H] D=[H],

  1. Use the equation in problem 3.1 to compute the probability of D \mathcal{D} D given a probability of heads. That is, find an expression for the likelihood term P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) P(\mathcal{D}|\theta) P(D‚à£Œ∏), which will be a function that depends on Œ∏ \theta Œ∏.

The P ( Œ∏ ) P(\theta) P(Œ∏) term in Bayes theorem above is the so-called prior. Assume you are an alien and know nothing about coin manufacturing machines and have never seen a coin tossed. In this case, based on your lack of subjective prior knowledge, you would say all values of Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ are equally likely and thus P ( Œ∏ ) = c P(\theta)=c P(Œ∏)=c, where c c c is a constant.

  1. In class, I mentioned that we often don‚Äôt need to worry about the term P ( D ) P(\mathcal{D}) P(D) because it is a constant that will ‚Äúcancel‚Äù. To elaborate, we are often interested in a ratio of probabilities such as P ( Œ∏ 1 ‚à£ D ) / P ( Œ∏ 2 ‚à£ D ) P(\theta_1|\mathcal{D})/P(\theta_2|\mathcal{D}) P(Œ∏1‚Äã‚à£D)/P(Œ∏2‚Äã‚à£D). For example, given a sequence of coin tosses from a coin manufactured by a new machine, we would want to know the ratio of the probability that a coin has a probability of heads of Œ∏ 1 \theta_1 Œ∏1‚Äã to the ratio that the probability of heads is Œ∏ 2 \theta_2 Œ∏2‚Äã. However, it is sometimes useful to compute this term explicitly. In this case, the law of total probability can be used: P ( D ) = ‚à´ 0 1 P ( Œ∏ ) P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) d Œ∏ \displaystyle P(\mathcal{D})=\int_0^1P(\theta)P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)d\theta P(D)=‚à´01‚ÄãP(Œ∏)P(D‚à£Œ∏)dŒ∏ Compute P ( D ) P(\mathcal{D}) P(D) in terms of c c c.

  2. Plot of P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) P(\theta|\mathcal{D}) P(Œ∏‚à£D) vs Œ∏ \theta Œ∏.

  3. Repeat parts 1.-3. for D = [ H , T ] \mathcal{D}=[H,T] D=[H,T].

  4. You are not an alien. Suppose your subjective judgment is that it is difficult to manufacture a coin with a probability of heads that differs much from 0.5. In equation form, you decide to use a sharply peaked Gaussian to represent this experience. That is, P ( Œ∏ ) ‚àù e ( Œ∏ ‚àí 0 . 5 ) 2 / 0 . 1 P(\theta) \propto e^{(\theta-0.5)^2/0.1} P(Œ∏)‚àùe(Œ∏‚àí0.5)2/0.1. Using this, plot P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) P(\theta|\mathcal{D}) P(Œ∏‚à£D) vs. Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ for D = [ H , T ] \mathcal{D}=[H,T] D=[H,T].

Save your answers in a file named HW3_3.pdf or HW3_3.md. Save your code in a file named HW3_3.py.

Answer

As discussed in class and on Discord, I used sloppy notation for the Law of Total Probability. When Œ∏ \theta Œ∏ is a parameter that can take on discrete values only, the Law of Total Proability is

P ( D ) = ‚àë Œ∏ P ( Œ∏ ) P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) \displaystyle P(\mathcal{D})=\sum_\theta P(\theta)P(\mathcal{D}|\theta) P(D)=Œ∏‚àë‚ÄãP(Œ∏)P(D‚à£Œ∏)

With N = 1 N=1 N=1 and k = 1 k=1 k=1, P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) = Œ∏ P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\theta P(D‚à£Œ∏)=Œ∏. This makes sense ‚Äì if Œ∏ = 0 \theta=0 Œ∏=0, the probability of getting D = [ H ] \mathcal{D}=[H] D=[H] is zero; if Œ∏ = 1 \theta=1 Œ∏=1, the probability is 1.

  2. If p ( Œ∏ ) = c p(\theta)=c p(Œ∏)=c, then by ‚à´ 0 1 p ( Œ∏ ) d Œ∏ = 1 \int_0^1p(\theta)d\theta=1 ‚à´01‚Äãp(Œ∏)dŒ∏=1, c = 1 c=1 c=1. Thus,

    P ( D ) = ‚à´ 0 1 p ( Œ∏ ) P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) d Œ∏ = 1 2 \displaystyle P(\mathcal{D})=\int_0^1p(\theta)P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)d\theta=\frac{1}{2} P(D)=‚à´01‚Äãp(Œ∏)P(D‚à£Œ∏)dŒ∏=21‚Äã

    ( c / 2 c/2 c/2 is also acceptable given the problem statement.)

    P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) = P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) P ( Œ∏ ) P ( D ) \displaystyle P(\theta|\mathcal{D})=P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)\frac{P(\theta)}{P(\mathcal{D})} P(Œ∏‚à£D)=P(D‚à£Œ∏)P(D)P(Œ∏)‚Äã

    gives

    P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) = 2 Œ∏ d Œ∏ \displaystyle P(\theta|\mathcal{D})=2\theta d\theta P(Œ∏‚à£D)=2Œ∏dŒ∏

    or, in terms of a probability density, using P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) = p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) d Œ∏ P(\theta|\mathcal{D})=p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta P(Œ∏‚à£D)=p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏

    p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) = 2 Œ∏ \displaystyle p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=2\theta p(Œ∏‚à£D)=2Œ∏

    Note that ‚à´ 0 1 p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) d Œ∏ = 1 \int_0^1 p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta=1 ‚à´01‚Äãp(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏=1 as expected based on inspection of Bayes‚Äô rule with the denominator written using the Law of Total Probability:

    P ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) = P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) P ( Œ∏ ) P ( D ) = P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) p ( Œ∏ ) d Œ∏ ‚à´ 0 1 P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) p ( Œ∏ ) d Œ∏ \displaystyle P(\theta|\mathcal{D})=P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)\frac{P(\theta)}{P(\mathcal{D})}=\frac{P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta)d\theta}{\int_{0}^1P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta)d\theta} P(Œ∏‚à£D)=P(D‚à£Œ∏)P(D)P(Œ∏)‚Äã=‚à´01‚ÄãP(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)dŒ∏P(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)dŒ∏‚Äã

    The plot is simply 2 Œ∏ 2\theta 2Œ∏. The main thing to get out of this is the interpretation. The maximum of P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) P(\mathcal{D}|\theta) P(D‚à£Œ∏) is at 0 . 5 0.5 0.5, as expected ‚Äì we are most likely to get D = [ H , T ] \mathcal{D}=[H,T] D=[H,T] if Œ∏ = 0 . 5 \theta=0.5 Œ∏=0.5. The final result is p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) = 6 Œ∏ ( 1 ‚àí Œ∏ ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=6\theta(1-\theta) p(Œ∏‚à£D)=6Œ∏(1‚àíŒ∏).

  5. If P ( Œ∏ ) ‚àù e ‚àí ( Œ∏ ‚àí 0 . 5 ) 2 / 0 . 1 P(\theta) \propto e^{-(\theta-0.5)^2/0.1} P(Œ∏)‚àùe‚àí(Œ∏‚àí0.5)2/0.1, then p ( Œ∏ ) ‚àù e ‚àí ( Œ∏ ‚àí 0 . 5 ) 2 / 0 . 1 p(\theta) \propto e^{-(\theta-0.5)^2/0.1} p(Œ∏)‚àùe‚àí(Œ∏‚àí0.5)2/0.1.     1 = ‚à´ 0 1 C e ‚àí ( Œ∏ ‚àí 0 . 5 ) 2 / 0 . 1 d Œ∏ \displaystyle 1 = \int_0^1 Ce^{-(\theta-0.5)^2/0.1}d\theta 1=‚à´01‚ÄãCe‚àí(Œ∏‚àí0.5)2/0.1dŒ∏

    Using an integration table or Wolfram Alpha, one can find this constant. In practice, this constant is not needed because we are generally interested in the shape of the curve of p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) p(Œ∏‚à£D), so that we only need to compute the right-hand side of

    p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) ‚àù P ( D ‚à£ Œ∏ ) p ( Œ∏ ) \displaystyle p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) \propto P(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta) p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚àùP(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)

    without regard to the proportionality constant. There are several things that you should observe. First, the Gaussian prior modifies the curve for p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) p(Œ∏‚à£D) so that it has more weight near 0 . 5 0.5 0.5 in comparison to the flat prior of p ( Œ∏ ) = c o n s t p(\theta)=const p(Œ∏)=const. If the prior was a delta function centered at 0 . 5 0.5 0.5, p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) p(Œ∏‚à£D) will be independent of D \mathcal{D} D. In Silva 2006, Figure 2.1. shows how p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) p(Œ∏‚à£D) changes as more trial results are added to D \mathcal{D} D. As the number of results in D \mathcal{D} D increases, p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) p(Œ∏‚à£D) becomes sharply peaked at the value Œ∏ = 0 . 2 5 \theta=0.25 Œ∏=0.25, which was used to generate D \mathcal{D} D.

    In Figure 2.2, p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) p(Œ∏‚à£D) is shown for a uniform prior (solid line), a Gaussian prior centered on Œ∏ = 0 . 5 \theta=0.5 Œ∏=0.5 (dashed line), and a U-shaped prior (dotted line). As the number of results in D \mathcal{D} D increases, p ( Œ∏ ‚à£ D ) p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) p(Œ∏‚à£D) for all three priors becomes sharply peaked around Œ∏ = 0 . 2 5 \theta=0.25 Œ∏=0.25, which was used to generate D \mathcal{D} D.

    A key conclusion is that as the number of results in D \mathcal{D} D increases, the influence of the prior decreases.

4.2 Bernoulli Trials

A Bernoulli Trial has

  • two possible outcomes;
  • the probability of ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù is p p p and the probability of ‚Äúfailure‚Äù is 1 ‚àí p 1-p 1‚àíp;
  • these probabilities don‚Äôt change

For N N N trials, the probability of k k k successes is represented by the Binomial distribution:

P ( k ) = ( N k ) p k ( 1 ‚àí p ) N ‚àí k \displaystyle P(k)={N \choose k}p^k(1-p)^{N-k} P(k)=(kN‚Äã)pk(1‚àíp)N‚àík

See also Devore, Chapter 3.4 where an experiment that conforms to the Bernoulli Trial constraints is referred to as a ‚ÄúBinomial Experiment‚Äù.

  1. Use a random number generator to simulate 10,000 Binomial Experiments with N = 1 0 0 N=100 N=100 trials and p = 0 . 4 p=0.4 p=0.4 and then plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k). (You‚Äôll have to research how exactly to ‚Äúuse a random number generator‚Äù to do this‚Äù.) On the same axes, plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k) expected from the equation above using the given N N N and p p p.
  2. Suppose p p p follows the rule: ‚ÄúIf two trials in a row are a success, the probability of success on the next trial increases by 10%; otherwise, the probability of success is p = 0 . 4 p=0.4 p=0.4‚Äù. Plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k) on the same axes as for part 1.

Save your code as HW4_2.py and save the plot as HW4_2.pdf. Be prepared to provide a justification in class for any differences between the two cases.

A follow-up question that I‚Äôll ask is if based on the two plots you can conclude that the second plot does not satisfy the constraints of a Binomial Experiment. Later in the semester, formal ways of answering this question will be covered. For now, I just want to hear your ideas about how you would approach the problem.

Answer

There was discussion on Discord about how the probability is to be changed. When writing the problem, I had in mind that the probability was either 0 . 4 0.4 0.4 or 0 . 4 4 0.44 0.44. But I think the problem statement is best interpreted as meaning that the p p p can continue to grow by 10%.

The motivation for allowing p p p to vary is that often you‚Äôll have a data set that does not quite conform to a certain set of assumptions. It is often useful to model the non‚Äìconformity to get an idea for how the non‚Äìconformity will change the results. In this problem, the varition in p p p models ‚Äúpersistence‚Äù. The most common form of persistence is that high‚Äìtemperature days tend to follow high‚Äìtemperature days. That is, the probability of a day having a high‚Äìtemperature is larger if the previous day had a high temperature.

There are several other points to discuss:

  1. How do we know if the simulation values are significantly different than the values from the formula? Could you determine this using concepts covered in previous HW problems? (We‚Äôll cover how to do this formally later.)
  2. The distribution looks Gaussian. How different from a Gaussian is it?

My code is at HW4_2.py. I solve the problem in two ways. In the first, I use a uniform probability distribution to generate a trial result with the given probabilities of success. In the second solution, I use np.random.binomial() to generate the trial results.

4.3 The Poisson Distribution

In class, I mentioned that the Poisson distribution can be derived as a limit of the Binomial distribution. This is also discussed in Devore 3.6.

If

  1. in a sufficiently short amount of time, Œî t \Delta t Œît, only 0 or 1 event can occur (two or more simultaneous events are impossible);
  2. the probability of exactly 1 event occurring in Œî t \Delta t Œît is equal to Œª Œî t \lambda \Delta t ŒªŒît, where Œª \lambda Œª is a constant; and
  3. any non-overlapping intervals of length Œî t \Delta t Œît are independent Bernoulli trials,

the probability of k k k events occurring in the time interval t = N Œî t t=N\Delta t t=NŒît is

P ( k ) = ( Œª t ) k e ‚àí Œª t k ! \displaystyle P(k)=\frac{(\lambda t)^k e^{-\lambda t}}{k!} P(k)=k!(Œªt)ke‚àíŒªt‚Äã

for sufficiently large N N N.

Use a random number generator to create a dataset that simulates the following result. Every hour, the number of x-ray flares is tabulated. It is found that over 1 0 0 0 1000 1000 days, 9 0 0 900 900 flares occurred so that the average probability of a flare in a given hour is 9 0 0 / ( 1 0 0 0 ‚ãÖ 2 4 ) 900/(1000\cdot 24) 900/(1000‚ãÖ24).

  1. Plot the probability of k k k flare events occurring per day for your simulated dataset. Also, plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k) expected from the equation above using the value of Œª \lambda Œª computed based on the problem description.
  2. From your dataset, derive a new dataset that is the time between flares and plot a histogram of the time between flares.

Answer

There were quite a few questions about this problem. It may make more sense to derive it without reference to time and then insert the time dependence at the end.

If p p p is the probability of event in time Œî t \Delta t Œît, and, by definition, Œª ‚â° p / Œî t \lambda \equiv p/\Delta t Œª‚â°p/Œît, then

P ( k ) = ( p t Œî t ) k e ‚àí p t Œî t k ! \displaystyle P(k)=\frac{(p\frac{t}{\Delta t})^k e^{-p \frac{t}{\Delta t}}}{k!} P(k)=k!(pŒîtt‚Äã)ke‚àípŒîtt‚Äã‚Äã

Next, using the definition t ‚â° N Œî t t\equiv N\Delta t t‚â°NŒît,

P ( k ) = ( p N ) k e ‚àí p N k ! \displaystyle P(k)=\frac{(p N)^k e^{-p N}}{k!} P(k)=k!(pN)ke‚àípN‚Äã

The interpretation is that if the probability of a success in a trial is p p p, then the probability of k k k successes in N N N trials is P ( k ) P(k) P(k).

A common use case for this equation is when an event takes a certain amount of time Œî t \Delta t Œît to occur (e.g., a hurricane or large solar flare). In this case, it makes sense to define a rate parameter which is the number events per unit time, which is Œª = p / Œî t \lambda=p/\Delta t Œª=p/Œît, where p p p is the probability of an event in Œî t \Delta t Œît. This variable corresponds with how we would describe the probability of an event, e.g., on average 0.01 hurricanes occur per day or in 100 days, 1 hurricane will occur.

It also make sense to talk not about the number of ‚Äútrials‚Äù, but rather the number of Œî t \Delta t Œîts, where each Œî t \Delta t Œît corresponds to a trial. In this case, we can define a time as t = N Œî t t=N\Delta t t=NŒît. This definition allows us to say ‚Äúgiven 0.01 hurricanes occur per day, what is the probability that 2 hurricanes occur in a month‚Äù.

Note that the the Poisson distribution is a good approximation of the Binomial distribution if N ‚â´ 1 N\gg 1 N‚â´1 and is valid for k p ‚â™ 1 kp\ll 1 kp‚â™1 and k / N ‚â™ 1 k/N\ll 1 k/N‚â™1.

My code is at HW4_3.py.

4.4 Solar Flare Data (590 only)

Only students registered in the graduate-level course (PHYS 590 or ASTR 590) need to turn in this assignment.

The zip file SOLAR_FLARES.zip contains the time of solar flares in an ASCII file named xray.txt; this is the only file that you will need for this problem. See the README file for information on how this file was created if you are interested.

Plot the probability distribution of the number of solar flares per day using xray.txt.

  1. Is the probability distribution similar to that expected from a Binomial Experiment or the Poisson distribution? If so, plot the equation for a Binomial Experiment and/or the Poisson distribution on the same axes as the histogram.
  2. Is the probability density of the time between solar flares similar to the probability density of the exponential distribution (see 4.4 of Devore)?
  3. Do the data conform to the constraints of a Binomial Experiment or the assumptions for the Poisson distribution?

Save any code or plots that you use to answer these questions in files with the prefix HW4_4. Be prepared to discuss your results in class.

Comments

These data were considered in Wheatland, 2000. The fit to both a binomial and Poisson distribution is poor. (I was glad to see that several students also plotted the binomial distribution because of concern that the assumptions Poisson approximation was not satisfied.) This is somewhat expected given that the probability that a flare occured in a given hour depends on whether a flare occured in the previous hour. From the data, I find (see HW4_4.py)

P ( F t ) = 0 . 2 7 P(F_t)=0.27 P(Ft‚Äã)=0.27

P ( F t ‚à£ F t ‚àí 1 ) = 0 . 0 8 P(F_t|F_{t-1})=0.08 P(Ft‚Äã‚à£Ft‚àí1‚Äã)=0.08, meaning that a flare is the least likely to occur in a given hour if one occured in the previous hour.

P ( F t ‚à£ F ‚Äæ t ‚àí 1 ) = 0 . 1 9 P(F_t|\overline{F}_{t-1})=0.19 P(Ft‚Äã‚à£Ft‚àí1‚Äã)=0.19

P ( F ‚Äæ t ‚à£ F ‚Äæ t ‚àí 1 ) = 0 . 5 4 P(\overline{F}_t|\overline{F}_{t-1})=0.54 P(Ft‚Äã‚à£Ft‚àí1‚Äã)=0.54

P ( F ‚Äæ t ‚à£ F t ‚àí 1 ) = 0 . 1 9 P(\overline{F}_t|F_{t-1})=0.19 P(Ft‚Äã‚à£Ft‚àí1‚Äã)=0.19

where F t F_t Ft‚Äã indicates a flare in hour t t t and F ‚Äæ t \overline{F}_t Ft‚Äã indicates no flare. The binomial distribution requires that these probabilities are all the same, which is clearly not the case. In addition, multiple flares occured in the same hour. If we define an event as a single flare, then the data are not consistent with the assumption that in each Œî t \Delta t Œît, only one event can occur. (We can work around this by defining an event as when one or more flares occured in a given hour.)

In writing the rule for the previous problem, I had mis-remembered the above result. That is, I had recalled that P ( F t ‚à£ F ‚Äæ t ‚àí 1 ) > P ( F t ‚à£ F t ‚àí 1 ) P(F_t|\overline{F}_{t-1}) > P(F_t|F_{t-1}) P(Ft‚Äã‚à£Ft‚àí1‚Äã)>P(Ft‚Äã‚à£Ft‚àí1‚Äã), which is opposite to what was observed.

5.2 Expectation Values

A summary (or descriptive) statistic is a quantity that summarize an aspect of a collection of data. Examples include the mean and standard deviation. Descriptive statistics are always based on a computation done on a sample (subset) of the population of data.

Definitions

  • Population - ‚ÄúAll‚Äù of the data is called the population. A population can be finite or infinite. An example of a finite population is all US citizens. An example of an infinite population are values from a continuous probability density function.
  • Sample statistic - a computation based on a sample from a population that gives an estimate of the equivalent value that would be obtained if the same computation was performed on the population. (Devore p214)

It is important that sample statistics are unbiased. If we compute a sample statistic based on a sample from a population and repeat this process many times we want the average of the sample statisic to be equal to the corresponding population statistic.

An example of an unbiased sample statistic is the average,

X ‚Äæ = 1 n ‚àë i = 1 n X i \displaystyle \overline{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_i X=n1‚Äãi=1‚àën‚ÄãXi‚Äã

Suppose we have a list of 1000 numbers with a mean Œº \mu Œº. If we draw n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100 numbers at random, compute the average X ‚Äæ 1 \overline{X}_1 X1‚Äã and repeat N ‚Üí ‚àû N\rightarrow \infty N‚Üí‚àû times, the average of these averages, will be Œº \mu Œº, the population average. Mathematically, this is

lim ‚Å° N ‚Üí ‚àû 1 N ‚àë i = 1 N X ‚Äæ i = Œº \displaystyle \lim_{N\rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N\overline{X}_i = \mu N‚Üí‚àûlim‚ÄãN1‚Äãi=1‚àëN‚ÄãXi‚Äã=Œº

The distribution of the X ‚Äæ i \overline{X}_i Xi‚Äã values is called the sampling distribution (Devore p214)

The general definition of the expectation operator E [ ‚ãÖ ] E[\cdot] E[‚ãÖ] is, for discrete x x x,

E [ X ] = ‚àë all  x x P ( x ) \displaystyle E \left[X\right] = \sum_{\text{all }x}xP(x) E[X]=all x‚àë‚ÄãxP(x)

or, for continuous x , x, x,

E [ X ] = ‚à´ x x p ( x ) d x \displaystyle E\left[X\right] = \int_{x}xp(x)dx E[X]=‚à´x‚Äãxp(x)dx

By definition, Œº = E [ X ] \mu=E\left[X\right] Œº=E[X]. That is Œº \mu Œº is the average of X X X over the population. The variance of a population is defined as

œÉ 2 = E [ ( X ‚àí Œº ) 2 ] \displaystyle \sigma^2=E\left[(X-\mu)^2\right] œÉ2=E[(X‚àíŒº)2]

An example of a biased sample statistic is

S b 2 = 1 n ‚àë i = 1 n ( X i ‚àí X ‚Äæ ) 2 \displaystyle S_{b}^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i-\overline{X})^2 Sb2‚Äã=n1‚Äãi=1‚àën‚Äã(Xi‚Äã‚àíX)2

Show that S b 2 S_{b}^2 Sb2‚Äã is biased by drawing n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from at normal distribution with Œº = 0 \mu=0 Œº=0 and œÉ = 1 \sigma=1 œÉ=1, computing S b 2 S_{b}^2 Sb2‚Äã and repeating N = 1 0 , 0 0 0 N=10,000 N=10,000 times. 6.1 Bootstraping a Sampling Distribution

Background Reading: Devore pages 251‚Äì252 (see Piazza) and my notes.

  1. Draw n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian distribution with Œº = 1 \mu=1 Œº=1 and œÉ = 1 \sigma=1 œÉ=1. Compute the test statistic Y = ‚àë i = 1 n X i 2 Y = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i^2 Y=‚àëi=1n‚ÄãXi2‚Äã. Repeat this 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 times. The probability density of these N = 1 0 , 0 0 0 N=10,000 N=10,000 values is an approximation of the sampling distribution of Y Y Y (if N = ‚àû N=\infty N=‚àû, it would not be an approximation). This approximate distribution is also called a ‚Äúparametric bootstrap‚Äù distribution ‚Äì the ‚Äúparametric‚Äù means that we know the sampling distribution of X X X.

If we don‚Äôt know the distribution of X X X, we can‚Äôt use the parametric bootstrap to get the sampling distribution of Y Y Y. However, we can use the non‚Äìparametric bootstrap to obtain an approximation of the sampling distribution of Y Y Y by drawing n n n values with replacement from the list of n n n measurements, computing Y 1 ‚àó Y^{*}_1 Y1‚àó‚Äã, and then repeating this 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 times. The distribution of 10,000 Y ‚àó Y^{*} Y‚àó values is a good approximation to the unknown sampling distribution of Y Y Y.

  1. Suppose your n n n measurements were [-0.546, -0.406, -0.115, -1.262, -1.386, -0.448, 0.829, 0.799, -1.100, 0.385]. Compute Y Y Y. Next, draw n n n values from the measurements with replacement and compute Y Y Y and call it Y 1 ‚àó Y^*_1 Y1‚àó‚Äã. Repeat this process B = 1 0 , 0 0 0 B=10,000 B=10,000 times and compute the probability density of Y ‚àó Y^{*} Y‚àó.

  2. Compare the two probability densities using a scatter plot. If Y is an array of the 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 values from part 1. and Ystar is an array of the 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 values from part 2., then np.histogram can be used as follows.

    # bin_edges = ... (do this yourself)
pdf, _ = np.histogram(Y, bins=bin_edges, density=True)
pdf_star, _ = np.histogram(Ystar, bins=bin_edges, density=True)
plt.plot(pdf, pdf_star, '.')

    Be prepared to answer questions about the interpretation of this plot.

Save your code in a file named HW6_1.py. When executed, the scatter plot should be shown.

Answer

As noted in the extensive discussion on Discord, the results are difficult to interpret. The reason is that the given n n n measurements were drawn from a distribution with Œº = 0 \mu=0 Œº=0 and not Œº = 1 \mu=1 Œº=1. In HW6_1.py and in the figures below, I used a set of n n n measurements drawn from a distribution with Œº = 1 \mu=1 Œº=1.

Based on this plot, we can conclude that the non-parametric bootstrap provides a sampling distribution that has a standard deviation that is similar to that of the parametric bootstrap. For N ‚Üí ‚àû N\rightarrow \infty N‚Üí‚àû, the parametric bootstrap distribution will approach the actual sampling distribution.

In general, you will use the non-parametric bootstrap to determine a confidence interval when the sampling distribution of the measurements is not known. In fact, this is the motivation for the non-parametric bootstrap. Oftwen we don‚Äôt know the sampling distribution (but almost as often, we assume to to be Gaussian or some other analytic equation). The advantage of the non-parametric bootstrap is that this assumption is not needed.

A useful discussion on comparing histograms.

6.2 Confidence Intervals when Sampling Distribution Known

Background reading: Chapter 7 of Devore and my notes.

The simplest problem for computing a confidence interval is

  1. n n n values are drawn from a Gaussian distribution;
  2. the population standard deviation, œÉ \sigma œÉ, is known;
  3. the statistic for which to compute a confidence interval is the mean.

When œÉ \sigma œÉ is not known (which is usually the case), we still know the sampling distribution of X ‚Äæ \overline{X} X. However, for small n n n, it is not Gaussian ‚Äì it is t n ‚àí 1 t_{n-1} tn‚àí1‚Äã‚Äìdistributed.

Draw n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian with Œº = 1 0 \mu=10 Œº=10 and œÉ = 1 \sigma=1 œÉ=1. Compute the 95% confidence interval for the mean

  1. using Equation 7.4 of Devore, and
  2. using Equation 7.15 of Devore;

  2. Verify your answer for 2. by drawing n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian with Œº = 1 0 \mu=10 Œº=10 and œÉ = 1 \sigma=1 œÉ=1 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000. Compute 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 confidence intervals. What fraction of these confidence intervals included Œº \mu Œº?

7.1 A Test on a Population Mean

In example 8.6 of Devore, a sample of n = 9 n=9 n=9 systems yielded an activation temperature of 1 3 1 . 0 8 131.08 131.08. The distribution of activation times was known (somehow) to be normal with a standard deviation of 1 . 5 1.5 1.5.

The following program draws samples from a normal population with Œº = 1 3 0 . 0 \mu=130.0 Œº=130.0 and œÉ = 1 . 5 \sigma=1.5 œÉ=1.5. With the random seed set, the sample mean is 1 3 0 . 0 8 130.08 130.08.

import numpy as np
np.random.seed(877)
x = np.random.normal(130.0, 1.5, size=9)
print(np.mean(x)) # 131.08
